captions.text:
We’re a month into 2015, and a lot of us
are probably struggling with our New Years
diet resolutions.

But if you find yourself staring at the half-eaten
donut in your hand saying, “why can’t

I quit you?”, don’t beat yourself up too
much.

New research out this week suggests that our
brains are hardwired to love that donut.

Writing in the publication Cell, scientists
at MIT say that they’ve discovered the neural
circuit that controls sugar and food addictions.

It’s called the LH-VTA Loop, and it’s
like a highway between the lateral hypothalamus,

or LH, which controls how hungry you feel,
and the ventral tegmental area, or VTA, which
is the center of the brain’s reward circuit.

Scientists knew that the LH-VTA Loop existed
-- problems in this area have been linked
to some sexual and drug addictions.

But they didn’t know if it was responsible
for food addiction, as well.

So to test its role in eating behavior, they
used a technique called optogenetics, on mice.

They genetically modified certain neurons
in the mice’s brains, so that those cells

could be basically turned on or off by exposing
them to light.

By delivering a yellow light through a small,
implanted fiber optic, the scientists could

turn those neurons on and activate the LH-VTA
Loop.

They could also turn those same neurons off
by delivering a blue light.

With these modifications in place, healthy,
well-fed mice were put into two stations.

The first had a cup full of food pellets,
and the second had a sugar dispenser. The
scientists then activated the yellow light.

With their reward circuits stuck in the “on”
position, the mice ate for longer periods

of time in the first station, and kept going
back to the sugar dispenser, repeatedly, at
the second station.

The mice at the second station would even
walk across a platform that delivered electrical
shocks just to get more of that sweet stuff.

But when the scientists used the blue light
to turn off the LH-VTA Loop, the mice wouldn’t

walk across the electrified platform, and
they wouldn’t eat if they were full.

Now, we humans also have this same Loop in
our brains, and it’s likely there for a
reason.

Many scientists believe that our taste for
what we now think of as junk food evolved

as a way to reward us for finding palatable,
high-energy food when food was scarce.

But, because we now live in a world with a
Krispy Kreme on every corner, our desire for

sugar has become more of a hinderance than
a help.

So, the scientists say that finding the part
of our brain that regulates these cravings

can help in developing treatments for often-debilitating
food addictions.

But, besides our brain’s reward system,
what else makes us love food?
Well, taste, of course.

There’s bitter, sweet, salty, sour and what’s
sometimes called the ‘fifth’ taste, known
as umami.

It’s best described as a savory -- but not
salty -- flavor that you can’t quite put
your finger on.

Umami flavor comes predominantly from high
levels of the amino acid glutamate and was
discovered by a Japanese scientist in 1908.

It’s found in cheeses, shiitake mushrooms,
ham, and monosodium glutamate, a food additive

that was developed in 1909 to enhance the
umami flavor of food.

Now, according to a new study in Japan, tasting
umami might be important to our health.

Scientists performed what’s known as a paper
filter disk test on 44 elderly patients. The

test uses a small piece of paper soaked in
different concentrations of a tasty solution

and places on the parts of the tongue responsible
for each taste.

And 16 percent of those tested turned out
to have unusually high thresholds for umami,
meaning that they could barely taste it.

And those same patients were also ones who
stated that food in general just wasn’t

palatable to them anymore. As a result, they
had suffered from loss of appetite and weight
loss.

Part of their problem, it turned out, was
hyposalivation, or the inability to produce
enough saliva.

You have to produce saliva in order to taste
anything, because food needs to be partially

dissolved by saliva for our taste buds to
register them.

And you know what actually stimulates saliva
production? Foods with umami in it!

So in a weird kind of catch-22, the patients
needed to eat more umami in order to taste
umami, to get their appetites back.

So the scientists prescribed a daily regime
of konbu-cha, a tea made from kelp that’s
rich in glutamate

The tea began stimulating their umami receptors,
which caused them to slowly increase saliva

production. And as they started to produce
more saliva, they began to taste foods more
strongly.

Eventually, food became more palatable and
they regained their appetite.

Thank you for watching this particularly delicious
episode of SciShow News. If you want to help

us share science with the world, you can become
a supporting subscriber at Subbable.com/scishow.

And don’t forget to go to youtube.com/scishow
and subscribe!

title: The Science of Sugar Addiction & The Fifth Taste

comments.author: ssarryo

comments.text:
I think people need to stop seeing the current state of "cruelty" to 
animals as being a requirement rather than an optional choice we make. All 
animals are naturally programmed to take each other out and use other 
animals for whatever purpose they require. Morality right/wrong is a human 
invention with no rules except for the ones we made. Caring about each 
other is one thing though, but caring about things not our species is a 
rather different and generous thing. There are of course some species we've 
actually evolved to work alongside or who have evolved to work alongside 
us, like dogs, horses, the organisms that are in or make up our very bodies 
etc. There are also other species' that work together and treat each other 
better because it's mutually beneficial. On the other hand, there are 
species' that are natural enemies and

Imagine if owls had the ability to create and do all the things we can. Do 
you reckon they'd be kind to mice and consider harming them immoral? Would 
lions all argue with each other over how "humanely" they should execute 
their prey? Would sharks not still be vicious assholes? Would spiders 
become vegetarians?

I think we have to give ourselves as a species some credit for how we treat 
animals. We DO really care, more than any other species, but at some point 
we have to accept that we are supposedly a dominant species and we have the 
capability to use and treat these animals in many ways, to certain extents. 
It seems like a weird train of thought, simply because we're so used to the 
practise of treating animals kindly. We are people who were all born into a 
world where this is was a rule. But humans invented this rule, we didn't 
live before then or during the long periods throughout history where 
"animal rights" has grown and grown to the point where it even starts to 
negatively impact our own species. Each generation of people looks at the 
old rules and thinks they can do one better... but the fact they think it's 
"better" is only based on the rule existing in the first place. If the 
rules were all to treat certain species' as specifically as possible for a 
particular reason, then THIS would be improved upon generation after 
generation... cognitive bias!

We keep tacking-on to rules which were completely optional in the first 
place. To a point, it was beneficial to us, which is most likely why the 
original rules came about. However the rules have been built on regardless 
of whether they're beneficial, because we just associate the rule existing 
with the rule being right and seeing how we can make the rule more 
powerful, without actually understanding why the rule exists. This is a 
problem which has most likely been hit by our communication. While most 
species have limited communication and don't generally pass down moral 
codes, we have the communication to pass down rules, however we use our 
communication in a limited capacity and fail to realise what another person 
needs communicating to them in order to understand the actual concept, and 
I think this has caused a lot of life's simple issues to become way more 
complex. We'll tell someone some rule is for good, but forget to mention 
that it's still optional, because we really want them to follow it, etc.

So, while we may still have the ability to say "right, wait a minute, where 
did these rules come from in the first place?", maybe we should realise 
that considering there are absolutely no rules in life, we are incredibly 
generous and peace-loving creatures (yeah, I know, doesn't seem like it 
right?). We judge each other harshly, based on rules that our ancestors all 
made up in the first place. Rules that weren't originally ever as strictly 
followed as they may be today. I think, to a certain extent, we really need 
to realise that, or we risk continually restricting our own progress. It's 
good that we have these rules, it shows we're worthy of calling ourselves 
superior, but lets not forget that we're superior and that no one gave us 
these rules except ourselves. If breaking them once or twice truly benefits 
us and others of our species, then we definitely ought to not let our own 
rules be our demise. This study could apparently help quite a lot of people 
for generations and generations to come, so I think an experiment on a few 
mice, whose lives aren't actually being taken from them or being made to 
suffer a whole lot, balances out fairly well. I just hope all of those mice 
got an equal opportunity to cross the electrified bridge to get to the 
sugar, because apparently the sugar was well worth that suffering in their 
own minds, so we can rest assured that we can do a certain amount to them 
as long as we give them a bowl of sugar afterwards. Like when you take a 
child for ice cream as a bribe.

+Jacques Lecockgrande All living things are conscious you moron. And it's 
pretty damn obvious to see that those mice do.

YES, even microorganisms like bacteria...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_intelligence

medieval times that had a shorter lifespan because of a lack of adequate

farmers. How often did Europeans bathe again?  According to a few sources, 
Europeans during the medieval era bathed only a few times A YEAR because 
they believed water carried diseases.  So, don't you think that fact must 
have been at least a good reason to why they had a shorter life span? Last 
time I checked, you don't have to murder an animal before you bath in order 
to live longer. Oh, and I prefer being a hippie, thanks.

comments.author: chocmilkshake24

comments.text:
This was incredibly upsetting to watch. I love SciShow along with Crash 
Course, vlogbrothers, etc., but this is very worrying. You guys did a video 
debunking the whole "areas of the tongue taste different flavors" thing, 
right?
Plus, "sugar addiction" is a ridiculous concept. Our bodies need glucose, 
so how can we be addicted to something we NEED? Too much of anything is 
bad, let's not make sugar out to be this horrible substance. It's not 
inherently bad. Eating in moderation (getting enough protein, fat, and 
carbs) to support your health/activity goals is the way to go, and an 
occasional donut won't kill you, or make you "addicted".
Please, please respond. The great thing about science is that we sometimes 
get it wrong, but we admit it and keep learning. I truly respect this 
channel and the people who are creating it, so I hope this gets a proper 
response.﻿

earth. canada is a close 7th [GO CANADA! drink that maple syrup!]) and the 
whole "hard wired to like junk food" thing is because of evolution and yeah 
its cool we found the exact pathway, but how is that important? dont sell 
it off as new information- because its not. 
on a side note- why do americans have to play things up so much? "___ 
university just discovered *__*!!! its not all that important but its 
A-FUCKING-MERICA!!!
i mean really? does your country not know humility? even the intellectuals 
arent humble.﻿
